newsitem.title: FRANCE: EMU without Italy unimaginable--BoF's Marchelli.
newsitem.headline: EMU without Italy unimaginable--BoF's Marchelli.

text.p: It would be unimaginable to launch a European single currency without Italy, while Spain and Portugal should also be in from the start, Bank of France monetary policy council member Paul Marchelli said on Friday.

And if this meant the new euro turned out to be less strong than Germany wanted, it would be a good thing for Europe as it struggles to bring down high unemployment, he told Reuters in a telephone interview.
"I cannot imagine the euro without Italy. It is impossible. It is like having Paris without the Eiffel Tower. It is ridiculous," he said. "We must have Italy, Spain and Portugal."
Greece was not going to be ready for the launch of the single currency in 1999, but should be helped to join as quickly as possible afterwards.
Marchelli, who does not shun controversy, spoke of anti-south racism.
He said Italy had made a tremendous effort to meet criteria for entry into a single currency and its only real problem stemmed from German fears that Italian membership would weaken the new euro.

"The Germans, who want a strong euro, in my opinion too strong a euro, tend to reject the southern countries," he said. "They fear the euro will not be strong enough. It is the only real problem of the Italians."

But he said the future of Europe had to be built on a balance between northern and southern countries and on a recognition of the need to fight unemployment, running at postwar records in some countries.
An overly strong euro might push unemployment higher.
"I want the euro to be created. I want Europe to be built. I also want people to be working in Europe.
"If the base for EMU is wider and if the currency is less strong than (Bundesbank President Hans) Tietmeyer hopes, that would be an excellent thing," he said.
Marchelli also said that if the government were to take public opinion into account, it would be clear that French people wanted Italy in the euro at the start.
He said it was narrow-minded to limit the debate on monetary union to whether it would launched on time in 1999.
"It is a completely secondary argument," he said.
And Germany, itself struggling to meet Maastricht treaty criteria, had to accept it alone could not run Europe.
"This anti-south racism will disappear," he said.
